descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Michael Jordan scored 16 points and had nine assists early, and Richard Hamilton scored a season-high 30 points as the Washington Wizards beat the Memphis Grizzlies 91-81 Tuesday night for their third straight victory.
article.headline: Wizards win third straight behind Hamilton's 30
article.linkText: Jordan gets help as Wizards roll on in Memphis
article.story:
MEMPHIS, Tenn. (AP) -- Michael Jordan knows he can score whenever he wants. He's just happier when he involves the rest of the Washington Wizards. Jordan scored 16 points and had nine assists, and Richard Hamilton scored a season-high 30 points as the Wizards beat the Memphis Grizzlies 91-81 on Tuesday night for their third straight victory. "You all know I'm capable of scoring if I have to," Jordan said. "If they get hot, I don't have to shoot the ball. I can just straight pass. If it looks like they need a little leadership, I'm not afraid to take more shots." In his previous two games, Jordan scored most of his points in the fourth quarter in helping the Wizards beat Houston and Dallas. But the Wizards trailed only once in their first game ever in Memphis, when they were down 27-26 in the first. They led 58-41 at halftime, thanks to a 13-6 run, and expanded their lead to 21 in the third. Jason Williams led the Grizzlies with 17 points and 11 assists. "He's still the greatest," said Grizzlies forward Rodney Buford, who guarded Jordan. "I mean he's older, but he's so much smarter. He thinks the game through now and makes the other guys better, and they feed off of it." Jordan showcased a few vintage moves for a sold-out crowd that gave him a standing ovation before tipoff. He had his tongue hanging out while driving the baseline and drawing a foul in the first, and made a few fallaway jumpers. He made four of his first six shots, before finishing 8-of-19. He was at his best with three assists in a two-minute span in the second. First, he found Christian Laettner for a 13-footer, then he passed to Brendan Haywood twice for dunks. "I felt like I was in the right place at the right time tonight," Haywood said. "Michael Jordan was feeding it to me, and I took advantage." Even when Jordan had a perfect opportunity to shoot over 5-foot-10 Brevin Knight in the fourth, he passed the ball. He played just 31 minutes, making sure he didn't aggravate the tendinitis in his right knee that forced him to sit out a game last week. Memphis gave Jordan a perfect chance to rest with Lorenzen Wright, Michael Dickerson and Stromile Swift all out with injuries. That opened up the middle for Haywood, who had 17 points and 15 rebounds. Jordan also did his part in coaching the Wizards while on the floor, putting his arm around Hamilton's neck at one point while offering advice. "I'm definitely not the future," Jordan said. Memphis coach Sidney Lowe said Jordan and the Wizards taught his own young Grizzlies a lesson. Pau Gasol, the Grizzlies' leading scorer, had just six points against Laettner. Jordan guarded Shane Battier, the player he passed over for Kwame Brown in June while still the Wizards' president. Jordan called Battier not a bad choice for any team Tuesday afternoon but said the Wizards couldn't pass up Brown's potential to be a "very special player." Battier didn't get a basket off Jordan in the first half, but finished with 14 points. He didn't hear any trash-talking from Jordan. "He's a very smart basketball player. He knows all the tricks of the trade besides being the greatest player of all-time," Battier said.

Game notes
Not getting to the free-throw line is turning into habit for Jordan. He went 152 games with a free throw until Nov. 27. He has now gone without a trip to the line in three games. ... The Grizzlies fielded approximately 175 credential requests for the game. ... The sellout was only the third back-to-back sellout in the Grizzlies' history and first since January 1996 while in Vancouver. ... An NFL contingent was in attendance with Memphis alumnus Isaac Bruce of the St. Louis Rams and Eddie George, Samari Rolle and Jevon Kearse of the Tennessee Titans.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
